abstracts.cdata!:
The modernization of the State Technical
            Assistance Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability
            as likely, institutional development impact as high, Bank
            performance as highly satisfactory, and Borrower performance
            as satisfactory. The main lessons learned with this project
            can be summarized as follows: Although modernization calls
            for an integrated approach so that all impediments to
            efficient performance of the public sector can be dealt with
            simultaneously, a "Christmas-tree" approach to
            modernization should not be pursued. Although this project
            succeeded in achieving its development objectives, in
            countries with political instability projects with a limited
            focus and short duration would be more appropriate.
            Political support at the highest level is crucial to enforce
            the utilization of financial management systems by all
            public sector agencies. Political commitment is
            indispensable not only to carry the implementation of a
            system but also to lead the enactment of necessary legal and
            regulatory improvements. The in-house development of a
            system for financial management would allow improvement of
            local expertise and increase the possibility of meeting
            national needs and priorities. The provision to and
            accessibility of public sector financial information by
            civil society and the public at large will contribute to the
            attainment of transparency, improvement in governance, and
            control of corruption.
